title: Understanding 'chmod 000' - The Self-Lockout

parts.explanation: Permission code: NOBODY gets ANY permissions (not even you!)
The file you're about to lock yourself out of

what_happens.step: Owner cannot write to the file
Nobody else can access it either
File becomes a 'ghost file' - visible but untouchable

real_world_impact: chmod 000 creates a 'ghost file' - you can see it exists, but you can't read it, edit it, or delete it normally. It's like locking yourself out of your own house and throwing away the key. You'll need root/sudo access to fix it.
prevention_tips: Never use chmod 000 unless you have a very specific security reason
If you want to protect a file, use chmod 400 (read-only for owner)
Remember: Even as the owner, 000 locks YOU out too
Use 'ls -l' to check permissions before changing them
If you accidentally do this, use 'sudo chmod 644 filename' to fix it
For truly sensitive files, consider encryption instead of permission tricks
